TEXT.English: The first 6 pieces of the Altar can only be created by sacrificing a Great Prophet, and even then only by Good or Neutral civilizations. The last piece has to be built.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les Luonnotar proclament que ce bloc de pierre est l'endroit où s'est tenu le Démiurge lorsqu'il vint en sa création avant la chute d'Agares. Chaque religion a un mythe différent sur l'origine de la pierre, mais aucune ne conteste sa puissance, toutes les unités créées par l'empire la possédant sont bénies.[PARAGRAPH:2]Les six premières parties de l'autel ne peuvent être construites qu'en sacrifiant un Prophète Illustre ou un Luonnotar, et seulement par une civilisation Bonne ou Neutre. La dernière partie doit être construite.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Luonnotar beteuern, dass der einzig wahre Gott auf diesem Stück Stein stand, als er vor dem Untergang von Agares auf die Erde kam. Jede Religion kennt ihren eigenen Mythos über die Herkunft dieses Steins, aber keine bestreitet seine Macht; jede Einheit, die in dem Reich aufgestellt wird, welches den Stein besitzt, erhält die Beförderung "Gesegnet".[PARAGRAPH:2]Die ersten sechs Teile des Altars können nur durch die Opferung eines Großen Propheten oder eines Luonnotar errichtet werden, und nur von Zivilisationen, die gut oder neutral sind. Der letzte Teil muss gebaut werden.
TEXT.Italian: I primi 6 pezzi dell'Altare possono essere creati solamente sacrificando un Grande Profeta, opzione disponibile solo alle civiltà Buone o Neutrali. L'ultimo pezzo dev'essere costruito nosrmalmente invece.
TEXT.Spanish: TAB]Los Luonnotar proclaman que este eslabón de piedra fue sobre el que el dios verdadero se mantuvo en pie cuando vino a la creación antes de la caída de Agares. Cada religión tiene un mito diferente acerca del origen de la piedra, pero ninguna disputa su control; todas las unidades creadas en el imperio que la posea serán Bendecidas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Las primeras 6 piezas del Altar sólo pueden ser creadas sacrificando un Gran Profeta o un Luonnotar, y solamente por civilizaciones Buenas o Neutrales. La última pieza debe ser construida.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Improves the health of all of the building civilization's cities on the same continent. Improves the heal rate of units in the city, and cures any that start the turn in the city of [LINK=PROMOTION_DISEASED]Disease[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_WITHERED]Withered[\LINK], and [LINK=PROMOTION_PLAGUED]Plagued[\LINK] afflictions.
TEXT.French: Améliore la santé de toutes les villes de la civilisation sur le même continent. Augment le taux de guérison des unités dans la ville et soigne la Maladie, l'Atrophie et la Peste pour toutes les unités présentes dans la ville au début du tour.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Verbessert die Gesundheit aller Städte des Erbauers auf dem Kontinent. Erhöht die Genesungsrate stationierter Einheiten und heilt kranke, atrophierte und verseuchte Einheiten, wenn sie die Runde in dieser Stadt beginnen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Migliora la salute di tutte le città, della civiltà che lo costruisce, sullo stesso continente. Migliora il tasso di guarigione delle unità in città, e cura chiunque sia [LINK=PROMOTION_DISEASED]Malato[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_WITHERED]Avvizzito[\LINK] e [LINK=PROMOTION_PLAGUED]Appestato[\LINK] se inizia il turno in città.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Mejora la salud de todos los edificios de las ciudades de la civilización en el mismo continente. Mejora el índice de curación de las unidades en la ciudad, y cura de Enfermedad, Debilidad y Plaga a cualquiera que empiece el turno en la ciudad.

TEXT.English: Commerce is the lifeblood of an empire. A farmer sells his prize horse to buy seed for next season, and the tax collector takes enough off the top to equip a footman. A noble buys a tapestry imported from across the continent, and the King's campaign can continue for another month. As such, it is not discontent that is the greatest threat to a ruler's ambition. Bread and carnivals can assuage unhappiness, or garrison troops should those measures fail. Rather a people's satisfaction has the potential to deplete the treasury and starve an empire. If the farmer is content with a smaller gain, from where does the soldier's arms come? If the noble is pleased with his bare halls, shall the war end sooner? Indeed, if the soldiers themselves do not yearn for a better life than their fathers, why will they quit the farm for a mercenary life?[PARAGRAPH:1]In light of this, the Stewards of Inequity make an offer which even rulers devoted to Junil have a hard time declining. Let the royal market be seeded with a relic of the King of Avarice here, or one of his praying acolytes there. Let his temples be unmolested in your capital. The people's hearts shall take up a little-just a little-greed. So will their labors be intensified with avarice, and the nation profit.[PARAGRAPH:1]Alas, such hubris has brought down empires. There is no such thing as a little greed, for Mammon is not a master content to share his subjects, and a people enslaved by their own base appetites are rare to rise to the nobler callings of man.
TEXT.French: Le Commerce est le sang d'un empire. Un fermier vend son cheval pour acheter des graines pour la saison suivante, et le collecteur de taxes prend assez pour équiper un milicien. Un noble achète une tapisserie importée de l'autre vout du continent, la campagne du Roi continue pour un autre mois. C'est pourquoi il n'est pas étonnant qu'il s'agit de la plus grande menace pour l'ambition d'un dirigeant. les pain et les fêtes peuvent calmer le mécontentement, ou la garnison si ces mesures échouent. La satisfaction du peuple a le potentiel pour vider la trésorerie et affamer un empire. Si le fermier est content avec un plus faible gain, d'ou viendront les armes du soldat?Si le noble est satisfait de ses murs nus, la guerre finira-t-elle plus tôt?Et même, si les soldats ne recherchaient pas une meilleure vie que celle de leur père, pourquoi quitteraient -ils leur ferme pour une vie de mercenaire?[PARAGRAPH:1]A la lumière de cela, les Intendants de l'Inéquité ont fait une offre que meme les dirigeants fanatiques de Junil peuvent difficilement décliner.Laissons dans le marché royal une relique du Roi de l'Avarice ici, ou l'un des ses acolytes priant là. Construisons ses temples intouchables dans notre capitale. Le cœur du peuple prendra alors un peu - juste un peu- d'avidité. Ainsi leur travail sera intensifié par l'avarice , et la nation en profitera.[PARAGRAPH:1] Hélas , une telle démesure a brisé des empires. Il n'est pas de petite avidité , et Mammon n'est pas un maitre prêt à partager ses sujets , et un peuple asservi à ses propre appétits est rarement apte à de plus nobles désirs de l'Homme.
TEXT.German: Handel ist der Puls eines jeden Reiches. Verkauft der Bauer sein bestes Pferd um Saatgut für das kommende Jahr zu kaufen, so nimmt ihm der Steuereintreiber genug davon ab, einen Krieger davon auszurüsten. Kauft der Adlige einen Gobelin vom anderen Ende der Welt, so kann des Königs Feldzug einen weiteren Monat andauern. Dies zeigt, nicht Unzufriedenheit ist die größte Bedrohung herrschaftlichen Ehrgeizes. Brot und Spiele vermögen das Volk zu beschwichtigen oder königlichen Truppen es niederzuwerfen. Im Gegenteil vermag Zufriedenheit, den Reichtum zu mindern und das Reich dadurch auszuhungern. Nimmt der Bauer die magere Ernte hin, woher bekommt der Krieger seine Waffen? Genügen dem Adligen seine leeren Hallen, wird der Krieg dadurch früher enden? Tatsache ist doch, wenn die Söldner nicht von einem besseren Leben als dem ihrer Väter träumen würden - warum sollten sie dann den Hof für ein Leben im Krieg aufgeben?[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Lichte dessen macht die Ungerichtigkeit ein Angebot, welches ein Herrscher selbst als Anhänger der Weisung nur schwer ablehnen kann. Bestückt den königlichen Markt mit Zeichen königlicher Habsucht hier, oder einem seiner Ministranten dort. Verlegt seine Tempel in Eure Hauptstadt. Pflanzt nur ein wenig Gier in die Herzen des Volks. So wird dessen Tun vom Streben nach mehr getrieben sein, zum Wohle der Nation.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ach, wieviele Länder sind an solch Hybris zugrunde gegangen! So etwas wie "ein wenig Gier" gibt es nicht, denn der Mammon ist kein Besitz von dem man abgeben will - und wer seinem Hunger danach einmal erlegen ist, der wird nur schwer zu nobler Gesinnung finden.
TEXT.Italian: Il commercio è la linfa vitale di un impero. Un contadino vende il suo miglior cavallo per comprare i semi per la prossima stagione, e l'esattore delle tasse prende il necessario per equipaggiare un soldato. Un nobile acquista un'arazzo importato dall'altra parte del continente, e la campagna del Re può continuare per un'altro mese. E cosi, non è il malcontento il pericolo più grande all'ambizione del sovrano. Pane e spettacoli possono mitigare il malcontento, altrimenti metti unità come guarnigione se quelle misure non dovesserò funzionare. Ovviamente la soddisfazione di una popolazione può portare a stagnare le finanze e far morire un impero. Se il contadino si accontenta di un guadagno minore, da dove arrivano i soldi per le armi per il soldato? Se il nobile è soddisfatto delle sue sale spoglie, la guerra dovrebbe finire prima? Ovviamente, se i soldati stessi non desiderassero una vita migliore di quella dei loro padri, perché abbandonerebberò la fattoria per una vita da mercenario?[PARAGRAPH:1]Alla luce di ciò, gli Amministratori della Disuguaglianza fanno un offerta che persino i sovrani devoti a Junil trovano difficile rifiutare. Lascia che il mercato regale abbia una reliquia del Re dell'Avarizia, o uno dei suoi accoliti che prega. Lascia i suoi templi nella capitale indisturbati. Il cuore delle persone diventarà un pò, solo un pò, più avido. Cosi il loro lavoro sarà intensificato dall'avarizia, e la nazione ne beneficierà.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ahimè, tale arroganza ha fatto crollare imperi. Non esiste una piccola avidità, perché Mammon non è un signore a cui vada di condividere i sudditi, e le persone schiave dei loro appetiti basilari difficilmente sentono la chiamata delle azioni più nobili.
TEXT.Spanish: El Comercio es la sangría de un imperio. Un granjero vende su preciado caballo para comprar semillas para la siguiente estanción, y el recaudador de impuestos colecta lo suficiente como para llenar el equipo de un hombre de a pie. Un noble compra un tapiz importado desde el otro lado del continente, y la campaña del Rey puede continuar otro mes. Así que esto es porque no es la insatisfacción la mayor amenaza para la ambición de un dirigente. El pan y los carnavales pueden calmar la infelicidad, o las tropas estacionadas harían que esas medidas fallaran. Por el contrario la satisfacción de la gente tiene el potencial de acabar con el tesoro y matar de hambre al imperio. Si el granjero está contento con una pequeña ganancia, ¿de dónde vienen las armas de los soldados? Si el noble está satisfecho con sus salas desnudas, ¿acabaría antes la guerra? De hecho, si los soldados no anhelan una vida mejor que sus padres, ¿por qué dejarán la granja por una vida de mercenario?[PARAGRAPH:1]A la luz de esto, los Encargados de la Desigualdad hacen una oferta que incluso a los devotos dirigentes de Junil les costaría declinar. Dejad que le mercado real sea instalado con una reliquia del Rey de la Avaricia aquí, o una de sus acólitos rezando allí. Dejad que sus templos no sean molestados en vuestra ciudad. Los corazones de la gente obtendrán un poco -sólo un poco- de codicia. De esta forma las labores se verán intensificadas con avaricia, y el beneficio de la nación.[PARAGRAPH:1]Al final, tan soberbia desmedida ha provocado la caída de imperios. No hay nada como un poco de codicia, Mammon no es un maestro que comparte sus conocimientos con avidez,y la gente esclavizada por sus propios apetitos básicos son difíciles de animar y llevar hacia la llamada más noble del hombre.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Legend says that a dragon was found so deep in slumber that his scales, teeth and horns were removed without him waking. More and more daring hunters stripped pieces from the dragon until he died, still locked within his dreams. The flesh was stripped and eaten, the hide cured and turned into armor. When only the bones were left, a Doviello warlord made it into his palace.[PARAGRAPH:1]Over the following centuries, marble towers, battlements, and fortifications were added to the palace until the original bones were completely hidden by the new construction, if they ever really existed. Those convinced of the legend say that the dragon's spirit still sleeps and that he will one day awake, most likely to destroy those that are living within his bones.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La légende raconte qu'un dragon a été découvert si profondément endormi que ses écailles, ses dents et ses cornes ont été enlevées sans le réveiller. Les chasseurs de plus en plus téméraires ont enlevé les parties du dragon jusqu'à ce qu'il meurt, toujours enfermé dans ses rêves. La chair a été enlevée et mangée, le cuir tanné et confectionné en armure. Quand seulement les os restèrent, un seigneur de guerre Doviello en a fait son palais.[PARAGRAPH:1]Au cours des siècles suivants, les tours de marbre, les créneaux et les fortifications ont été rajoutés au palais jusqu'à ce que les os originaux soient complètement cachés par les nouvelles constructions, s'ils ont jamais vraiment existé. Ceux convaincu de la légende disent que l'esprit du dragon dort toujours et qu'un jour il se réveillera, fort probablement pour détruire ceux qui vivent dans ses os.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Legende erzählt, dass ein Drachen so tief im Schlaf versunken war, dass ihm Schuppen, Zähne und Hörner entfernt werden konnten, ohne dass er erwachte. Immer mehr waghalsige Jäger schnitten Stücke aus seinem Leib, dass der Drache, noch immer in seinen Träumen gefangen, schließlich starb. Sein Fleisch wurde verzehrt, seine Haut getrocknet und für Rüstungen verwendet. Als nur noch die Knochen übrig waren, machte ein Kriegsfürst der Doviello seinen Palast daraus.[PARAGRAPH:1]Während der folgenden Jahrhunderte wurde der Palast durch marmorne Türme, Mauerzinnen und Befestigungsanlagen erweitert, bis die Knochen vollständig unter den neuen Erweiterungen verschwunden waren. Die, die an die Legende glauben, sind überzeugt, dass der Geist des Drachen noch immer schläft und dass er eines Tages erwachen wird, um die zu zerstören, die in seinen Knochen wohnen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Le leggende raccontano che un drago fu trovato che dormiva cosi profondamente che le sue scaglie, denti e corna furono rimosse senza che lui si svegliò. Cacciatori sempre più audaci staccarono pezzi dal drago fino a quando non morì, ancora immerso nei suoi sogni. La carne fu staccata e mangiata, la pelle trattata e usata per armature. Quando solo le ossa rimasero, un signore della guerra Doviello le usò per creare il suo palazzo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nei successivi secoli, torri di marmo, merli, e fortificazioni furono aggiunte al palazzo fino a quando le ossa originali furono completamente nascoste dalle nuove costruzioni, se sono mai esistite veramente. Coloro che credono alla leggenda dicono che lo spirito del drago ancora dorme e che un giorno si sveglierà, molto probabilmente per distruggere coloro che vivono all'interno delle sue ossa.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Cuenta la leyenda que una vez se encontró un dragón tan profundamente dormido que sus escamas, dientes y cuernos se le fueron arrebatado sin siquiera ser despertado. Cada vez más y más cazadores osados fueron quitándole trozos al dragón hasta que éste murió, aún estando atado a sus sueños. Su carne fue cortada y devorada, y su piel tratada y convertida en una armadura. Cuando sólo quedaron los huesos, un señor de la guerra Doviello mandó con ellos construir un palacio para sí.[PARAGRAPH:1]Durante los siguientes siglos, torres de marfil, almenas y fortificaciones se fueron anexionando al palacio hasta que los huesos originales quedaron completamente escondidos bajo la nueva edificiación, si es que existieron realmente. Aquellos que creen en la leyenda dicen que el espíritu del dragón aún duerme y que despertará algún día, seguramente para destruir a aquellos que viven dentro de sus huesos.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Provides [LINK=BONUS_ALE]Ale[\LINK] resource. Also increases commerce in the city by 10% if Corn, Rice, or Wheat is available and grants +2 xp to dwarves built in the city. It can only be built along a river.
TEXT.French: Augmente le bonheur de 1 si du maïs, du riz ou du blé sont disponibles. La brasserie doit être construite sur la berge d'une rivière. Les nains construits dans la ville commencent avec 2 EXP supplémentaires.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Erhöht die Zufriedenheit um +1 wenn Mais, Reis oder Weizen verfügbar sind. Brauhäuser können nur an Flüssen gebaut werden.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Fornisce la risorsa [LINK=BONUS_ALE]Birra[\LINK]. Aumenta inoltre il commercio del 10% se il Granoturco, Riso, o il Frumento è disponibile e fornisce +2 PE (XP) ai nani creati in città. Può essere costruita solo in una città sul fiume.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Aumenta la felicidad en 1 si hay Maíz, Arroz o Trigo, y proporciona +2 de xp a los enanos instruidos en la ciudad. Las cervecerías sólo pueden construirse al lado de un río.

TEXT.English: Sebill arrived at a door marked "Acquisitions." The coachman escorted her to the door and gave it two hard knocks. It opened to reveal a miniscule butcher. The dwarf looked up at the coachman and noted Sebill. "Good! Good!" he said and ushered them into what looked like a carpenter's workshop-only one in which the wood bled when cut. "I commend you on your haste; we here are great appreciators of body magic, you know. You ought to be well paid for your effort. Do you need new horses?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"They are well," answered the coachman, "they're of strong breed and can withstand the spells. With enough food and rest tonight they'll have their stamina back."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"They're fine animals, aren't they?" the dwarf said affably, clearing tools off a table. He was joined by a graying female dwarf wearing an equally dirty apron. "Splendid!" she said. "Let's get started. I'm Odea, he's Hahm, in case he didn't introduce himself."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Anton," said the coachman.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Odea turned to examine Sebill. "Let's get a look at you... Even better than I expected! Let's get you on the table." Anton stepped forward to help lift Sebill, but saw it was unnecessary as Odea, despite her size, moved Sebill to the dwarf-sized table without effort. Odea smiled, "She's empty. No organs. I asked our clients in Nubia to clean her to prevent spoiling. Kept out of the sun the bodies can make the trip in adequate shape." Anton nodded. Odea thought he seemed uneasy. "I'm sorry, did you know her?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No, no... I have no idea who she is, or why she's important to the nobles. She doesn't look like an aristocrat." He paused, then motioned toward the door, "I have the rest of the delivery in my carriage."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Her blood I'm sure. Would you fetch that? Hahm needs to check it and make sure the preservers held up. There are a number of naturally occurring blood thinners in just about every land, but ours are better. I have some theories about speeding the reactions to make the ink less corrosive, but that would require entropy mana which can be hard to come by..."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Outside, Anton gave the blood to Hahm and moved his horses into the shade. This was his first visit to the Luchuirp lands. He admitted to himself that he'd always been a little racist toward dwarves, but couldn't think of any reason why. He looked at and admired the structure of the Catacomb Libralus; from what he'd heard he assumed it was nothing more than a one-trick curiosity shop. It was originally built as a catacomb open to all, until necromancers developed a habit of exploiting it, leading to the pejoration of the name "Free-Use Catacombs." Later it was acquired by a wealthy polymath, who turned it into the institution that is now commonly nicknamed the "Catacomb Librarius." Above ground it was a simple structure with short walls and an entrance adorned with arches and pillars.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton returned to the workshop to see Odea in the process of skinning Sebill. Incisions ran up the middle of her chest, along her collarbone, and above her hips. Odea was paring the fatty membrane holding skin to muscle as she pulled the skin upward. Anton groaned at the sight, which alerted Odea that he'd returned. She explained, her enthusiasm outweighing her sympathy for Anton's uneasiness, "The skin's in good shape. We use it all. Her back-because its smoother and thicker-will be tanned and used to make the cover. The rest we stretch into vellum for the pages." Odea paused, Anton was staring at Sebill's body. "It's not pretty, I know. This is an honorable afterlife though. I used to do golemcraft, but animating a golem is like rolling a stone down a hill-it's predictable, it's all it does. Books are the perfect synthesis of form and function, body and spirit, mythos and logos. They are us in every way." She put down her knife, and Anton sat on short ladder. Odea continued, "We can put any talent to use here. Do you practice magic?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I do some, just tricks to help my deliveries-speed the horses, hide my wares. Just dabblings."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ice! Imagine what you could do with ice mana! We could add people from any corner of Erebus to our collection. You could make your fortune just transporting food to soldiers. Ah, if only we could get some..." Anton laughed. He'd thought of this before. Odea continued, "We use a range of magic here: body helps us transform the person, but that's mostly handiwork; our diviners use spirit magic to contact the dead; and enchanters can infuse the books with special properties. Luckily we're in a land where necromancy is outlawed, or we'd have a lot to worry about. Should I take you to see some of our collection?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Thank you," he replied, "but I have to stable my horses first. I should find an inn."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Fine by me. I need to work and I can't have distractions. Come back later for a tour." Odea smiled, "Now get out of here."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A week had passed since Anton delivered Sebill. He'd gone north to meet a Calabim rendezvous who took the carriage, leaving Anton with a horse. Now returning to the fortified city, he spent the evening at a public house, waiting for nightfall. He made his way back to the Catacomb Libralus and to the door marked "Acquisitions." He knocked. If Odea answered he'd have an excuse for being there. If she didn't, then things would be according to plan. He picked the lock and slipped inside. There was barely any light and he waited for his eyes to adjust. The tables were clean and the tools put away. A door in back opened to a lantern-lit corridor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When he entered the main hall he realized he'd underestimated the age and grandeur of this place. He thought the library at his former mages' guild was large, but he'd never seen this many books. The hall was lined with shelves of books in every skin color, all facing out. Numerous corridors descended into the catacombs, all filled with books. Anton despaired when he wondered how he would find a single book in all this, until he saw the years inscribed above the corridors' arches.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He entered the most recent corridor, which had just started to be used in the last five years. He walked straight to the end of the row. A small engraving was underneath the last book. Some Malakim name; the book was too dark anyway and had a tattoo of a lion on the cover. The second-to-last book was a pale tan, like a dry meadow. The engraving underneath read "unknown" and named the year of death. The book before that was grayish green and had a single horn jutting out from the spine. He picked up the tan one. It was about two hands tall and a little less wide. The cover was soft-it was leather after all. The spine was sturdy. Bone? He imagined it was her sternum, and thought of her breasts, one skinless, the other just dead. He opened the cover and ran his finger along the inside spine. The pages were sewn to the cover using string made of brown hair. There was writing on the first page, in ink that was still reddish and had not faded into brown. It said: My dear Ain-You'll never read this, but please know that I love you eternally. A chill shook him. He tucked Sebill's book into his pack and returned to the main hall.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He looked at the dates above the arches, and walked down the next corridor. Both sides of the corridor were lined with books facing each other. A jumble of names grew in his head as he scanned the engravings.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Are you looking for something, Anton?" He spun to see Odea in the middle of the corridor. She looked relaxed; he tried his best to appear the same. Her apron was gone and she was dressed comfortably, striking Anton as quite pretty.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Um... yes. A book. A book of... my grandfather."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Anything else?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"...No."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"What was his name?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton glanced toward the main hall to see if Odea was alone. "Gerard Cormand."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I know of him! Quite the revolutionary in his day. Did you know him?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I didn't. My father opposed his politics and left the city, taking his family along. I was born on a farm."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Your grandfather was murdered before the revolution ended, wasn't he?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes. I have to know that it wasn't... my father."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Your grandfather is here," she pointed farther down the corridor. Anton cautiously followed her lead. "Our diviners enjoy limited success as a writing tool for the dead, allowing them to make a final statement."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"The dead write?" probed Anton.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We ask them if there's anything they'd like to say. They're usually thinking about what they would have done differently in life, so they're full of advice. They might eulogize themselves, or tell their entire life's story-we give the diviners a short vacation to recover after those. These are good souls, mind you; we don't even want to know the dangers of making an unscrupulous book."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"That woman," thought Anton, "what had she done to make her so valuable to the Calabim?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Victims of murder usually have something to say..." Odea stopped walking and motioned toward a book, smaller than Sebill's and paler.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton said, "Would he have named his killer?" Odea didn't answer, and Anton lifted his grandfather's book. He opened it and read: I liked the fleshy sins best. He turned the pages: blank. He sighed deeply, and put the book down. Odea took a step back. "Are you going to return the other book too?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton faced Odea with a widened stance. "No. I'm sorry, but I'm stealing it." He held a knife at her eye level and took a slow step toward her.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I can't stop you," she said calmly. "This is a mistake though. These books are extremely dangerous in the wrong hands. They must never leave."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I know. Your clients' haven't given me any choice though." They circled each other in a cautious dance. Seeing the main hall clear, Anton left through the front door.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Outside the city walls, Anton snuck to his horse, mounted her, and pointed her back north. "I commend you on your haste; we here are great appreciators of body magic, you know. You ought to be well paid for your effort. Do you need new horses?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"They are well," answered the coachman, "they're of strong breed and can withstand the spells. With enough food and rest tonight they'll have their stamina back."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"They're fine animals, aren't they?" the dwarf said affably, clearing tools off a table. He was joined by a graying female dwarf wearing an equally dirty apron. "Splendid!" she said. "Let's get started. I'm Odea, he's Hahm, in case he didn't introduce himself."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Anton," said the coachman.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Odea turned to examine Sebill. "Let's get a look at you... Even better than I expected! Let's get you on the table." Anton stepped forward to help lift Sebill, but saw it was unnecessary as Odea, despite her size, moved Sebill to the dwarf-sized table without effort. Odea smiled, "She's empty. No organs. I asked our clients in Nubia to clean her to prevent spoiling. Kept out of the sun the bodies can make the trip in adequate shape." Anton nodded. Odea thought he seemed uneasy. "I'm sorry, did you know her?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No, no... I have no idea who she is, or why she's important to the nobles. She doesn't look like an aristocrat." He paused, then motioned toward the door, "I have the rest of the delivery in my carriage."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Her blood I'm sure. Would you fetch that? Hahm needs to check it and make sure the preservers held up. There are a number of naturally occurring blood thinners in just about every land, but ours are better. I have some theories about speeding the reactions to make the ink less corrosive, but that would require entropy mana which can be hard to come by..."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Outside, Anton gave the blood to Hahm and moved his horses into the shade. Later it was acquired by a wealthy polymath, who turned it into the institution that is now commonly nicknamed the "Catacomb Librarius." Above ground it was a simple structure with short walls and an entrance adorned with arches and pillars.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton returned to the workshop to see Odea in the process of skinning Sebill. Incisions ran up the middle of her chest, along her collarbone, and above her hips. Odea was paring the fatty membrane holding skin to muscle as she pulled the skin upward. Anton groaned at the sight, which alerted Odea that he'd returned. She explained, her enthusiasm outweighing her sympathy for Anton's uneasiness, "The skin's in good shape. We use it all. Her back-because its smoother and thicker-will be tanned and used to make the cover. The rest we stretch into vellum for the pages." Odea paused, Anton was staring at Sebill's body. "It's not pretty, I know. This is an honorable afterlife though. I used to do golemcraft, but animating a golem is like rolling a stone down a hill-it's predictable, it's all it does. Books are the perfect synthesis of form and function, body and spirit, mythos and logos. They are us in every way." She put down her knife, and Anton sat on short ladder. Odea continued, "We can put any talent to use here. Do you practice magic?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I do some, just tricks to help my deliveries-speed the horses, hide my wares. Just dabblings."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ice! Imagine what you could do with ice mana! We could add people from any corner of Erebus to our collection. You could make your fortune just transporting food to soldiers. Ah, if only we could get some..." Anton laughed. He'd thought of this before. Odea continued, "We use a range of magic here: body helps us transform the person, but that's mostly handiwork; our diviners use spirit magic to contact the dead; and enchanters can infuse the books with special properties. Luckily we're in a land where necromancy is outlawed, or we'd have a lot to worry about. Should I take you to see some of our collection?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Thank you," he replied, "but I have to stable my horses first. I should find an inn."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Fine by me. I need to work and I can't have distractions. Come back later for a tour." Odea smiled, "Now get out of here."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A week had passed since Anton delivered Sebill. He'd gone north to meet a Calabim rendezvous who took the carriage, leaving Anton with a horse. Now returning to the fortified city, he spent the evening at a public house, waiting for nightfall. He made his way back to the Catacomb Libralus and to the door marked "Acquisitions." He knocked. If Odea answered he'd have an excuse for being there. If she didn't, then things would be according to plan. He picked the lock and slipped inside. There was barely any light and he waited for his eyes to adjust. The tables were clean and the tools put away. A door in back opened to a lantern-lit corridor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When he entered the main hall he realized he'd underestimated the age and grandeur of this place. He thought the library at his former mages' guild was large, but he'd never seen this many books. The hall was lined with shelves of books in every skin color, all facing out. Numerous corridors descended into the catacombs, all filled with books. Anton despaired when he wondered how he would find a single book in all this, until he saw the years inscribed above the corridors' arches.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He entered the most recent corridor, which had just started to be used in the last five years. He walked straight to the end of the row. A small engraving was underneath the last book. Some Malakim name; the book was too dark anyway and had a tattoo of a lion on the cover. The second-to-last book was a pale tan, like a dry meadow. The engraving underneath read "unknown" and named the year of death. The book before that was grayish green and had a single horn jutting out from the spine. He picked up the tan one. It was about two hands tall and a little less wide. The cover was soft-it was leather after all. The spine was sturdy. Bone? He imagined it was her sternum, and thought of her breasts, one skinless, the other just dead. He opened the cover and ran his finger along the inside spine. The pages were sewn to the cover using string made of brown hair. There was writing on the first page, in ink that was still reddish and had not faded into brown. It said: My dear Ain-You'll never read this, but please know that I love you eternally. A chill shook him. He tucked Sebill's book into his pack and returned to the main hall.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He looked at the dates above the arches, and walked down the next corridor. Both sides of the corridor were lined with books facing each other. A jumble of names grew in his head as he scanned the engravings.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Are you looking for something, Anton?" He spun to see Odea in the middle of the corridor. She looked relaxed; he tried his best to appear the same. Her apron was gone and she was dressed comfortably, striking Anton as quite pretty.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Um... yes. A book. A book of... my grandfather."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Anything else?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"...No."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"What was his name?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton glanced toward the main hall to see if Odea was alone. "Gerard Cormand."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I know of him! Quite the revolutionary in his day. Did you know him?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I didn't. My father opposed his politics and left the city, taking his family along. I was born on a farm."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Your grandfather was murdered before the revolution ended, wasn't he?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes. I have to know that it wasn't... my father."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Your grandfather is here," she pointed farther down the corridor. Anton cautiously followed her lead. "Our diviners enjoy limited success as a writing tool for the dead, allowing them to make a final statement."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"The dead write?" probed Anton.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We ask them if there's anything they'd like to say. They're usually thinking about what they would have done differently in life, so they're full of advice. They might eulogize themselves, or tell their entire life's story-we give the diviners a short vacation to recover after those. These are good souls, mind you; we don't even want to know the dangers of making an unscrupulous book."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"That woman," thought Anton, "what had she done to make her so valuable to the Calabim?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Victims of murder usually have something to say..." Odea stopped walking and motioned toward a book, smaller than Sebill's and paler.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton said, "Would he have named his killer?" Odea didn't answer, and Anton lifted his grandfather's book. He opened it and read: I liked the fleshy sins best. He turned the pages: blank. He sighed deeply, and put the book down. Odea took a step back. "Are you going to return the other book too?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton faced Odea with a widened stance. "No. I'm sorry, but I'm stealing it." He held a knife at her eye level and took a slow step toward her.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I can't stop you," she said calmly. "This is a mistake though. These books are extremely dangerous in the wrong hands. They must never leave."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I know. Your clients' haven't given me any choice though." They circled each other in a cautious dance. Seeing the main hall clear, Anton left through the front door.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Outside the city walls, Anton snuck to his horse, mounted her, and pointed her back north. He hadn't ridden far when a sudden strong wind, or that's what it felt like, threw him off his horse, spilling his pack. Instead, he died at the forest's edge a short length away, while the Book of Sebill remained beside the road.

TEXT.Italian: Sebill arrivò a una porta contrassegnata "Acquisizioni". Il cocchiere l'accompagnò alla porta e bussò forte due volte. Si aprì rivelando un minuscolo maccellaio. Il nano guardo il cocchiere e notò Sebill. "Bene! Bene!" disse facendoli entrare in quello che poteva sembrare il laboratorio di un carpentiere, solo se il legno sanguina quando viene tagliato. "Mi congratulo per la vostra celerità; noi qui siamo grandi estimatori della magia del corpo sapete. Spero verrai ben pagato per il tuo lavoro. Hai bisogno di nuovi cavalli?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Loro stanno bene," rispose il cocchiere, "sono di razzo robusta e possono sopportare le magie. Con sufficente cibo e riposo stanotte recupereranno le forze."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Sono dei bei animali, non è vero?" il nano disse affabilmete, togliendo gli strumenti dal tavolo. Si unì a lui un nana brizzolata che indossava un grembiule altrettanto sporco. "Splendido!" disse lei. "Mettiamoci al lavoro. Sono Odea e lui è Hahm, nel caso non si sia presentato."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Anton," disse il cocchiere.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Odea si voltò ad esaminare Sebill. "Diamoti un'occhiata... Anche meglio di quanto mi aspettavo! Mettiamoti sul tavolo." Anton si fece avanti per aiutare a sollevare Sebill, ma vide che non era necessario mentre Odea, nonostante le sue dimensioni, spostava Sebill verso il piccolo tavolo. Odea sorrise, "È vuota. Niente organi. Ho chiesto ai nostri clienti di Nubia di ripulirla per evitare la decomposizione. Se tenuti lontani dal sole i corpi possono fare un viaggio quasi senza problemi." Anton annuì. Odea pensò che era a disagio. "Mi dispiace, la conoscevi?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No, no... Non ho idea di chi fosse, o perché sia importante per i nobili. Non sembra un aristocratica". Attese un pò, poi si diresse verso la porta, "Ho il resto della spedizione nella mia carrozza."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Il suo sangue sicuramente. Puoi andare a prenderlo? Hahm deve controllarlo e assicurarsi che i conservanti siano ancora attivi. CI sono un certo numero di fluidificanti del sangue naturali in ogni terra, ma i nostri sono migliori. Ho qualche teoria sul come accellerare la reazione per rendere l'inchiostro meno corrosivo, ma ciò richiede mana dell'entropia, che può essere difficile da recuperare..."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Fuori, Anton diede il sangue ad Hahm e spostò i suoi cavalli nell'ombra. Questa era la sua prima volta nelle terre Luchuirp. Riconobbe che era sempre stato un pò razzista verso i nani, ma non riusciva a pensare a nessun motivo del perché. Contemplò la struttura del Catacomba Libralus; da quello che aveva sentito pensava non fosse altro che un negozio di curiosità unico. È stata costruita originalmente come una catacomba aperta a tutti, fino a quando i nocromanti non svilupparono l'abitudine di sfruttarla, portando alla creazione del nome "Catacombe ad Uso Gratuito". Più tardi fu comprata da un ricco tuttologo, che la trasformo in un'istituzione che ora viene comunamente soprannominata "Catacomba Librarius". In superfice è una struttura semplice, con muri bassi, e un'ingresso adornato con archi e pilastri.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton ritornò al laboratorio vedendo Odea scuoiare Sebill. Le incisioni erano al centro del petto, lungo la clavicola, e sopra l'anca. Odea stava tagliando la membrana che teneva la pelle legata al muscolo man mano che tirava la pelle in alto. Anton emise un verso a quella vista, che allertò Odea del suo ritorno. Lei spiego, la sua simpatia per il disagio di Anton superata dal suo entusiasmo, "La pelle è in buono stato. La usiamo tutta. La schiena, perché più liscia e spessa, sarà conciata e usata per fare la copertina. Il resto lo usiamo per fare le pagine." Odea si fermò, Anton stava fissando il corpo di Sebill. "Non è bello, lo so. Questa è comunque un'onorevole vita dopo la morte. Ero solita creare golem, ma animare un golem è come far rotolare un sasso giu da una collina, è prevedibile, in tutto ciò che fa. I libri sono la sintesi perfetta di forma e funzione, corpo e spirito, miti e leggende. Sono noi, in ogni modo". Posò il coltello, e Anton sedette su una piccola scaletta. Odea continuò, "Abbiamo lavoro per chiunque qui. Tu pratichi la magia?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Qualcosina, solo trucchetti per facilitare le mie consegne, far andare più veloce i miei cavalli o nascondere le merci."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ghiaccio! Immagina cosa potresti fare con del mana del ghiaccio! Potremmo aggiungere persone da ogni angolo di Erebus alla nostra collezione. Potresti fare una fortuna solamente trasportando il cibo ai soldati. Ah, se solo potessimo ottenere un pò di..." Anton rise. Lui ci aveva già pensato. Odea continuò, "Usiamo diverse magie qui: quella del corpo ci aiuta a trasformare la persona, ma quello è maggiormente un lavoro manuale; i nostri divinatori usano la magia dello spirito per contattare i morti; e gli incantatori possono infondere i libri con capacità speciali. Fortunatamente siamo in un posto dove la necromanzia non è fuorilegge, altrimenti avremmo parecchio di cui preoccuparci. Ti va di vedere qualcuna delle nostre collezioni?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Grazie," Anton rispose, "ma devo pensare ai miei cavalli prima. Dovrei trovare una locanda."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Va bene. Devo lavorare e non posso avere distrazioni. Torna più tardi per un giro." Odea sorrise, "Ora fuori di qui."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Passò una settimana da quando Anton consegnò Sebill. Lui andò a nord per incontrare un Calabim con cui aveva appuntamento che prese la sua carrozza, lasciando un cavallo ad Anton. Ora tornava alla città fortificata, passò la sera in un'osteria, aspettando la notte. Tornò alla Catacomba Libralus e alla porta contrassegnata "Acquisizioni". Bussò. Se Odea rispondeva aveva già una scusa sul perché era di nuovo li. Se non rispondeva, le cose sarebbero andate secondo il piano. Scassinò la serratura e scivolò dentro. Non c'era quasi luce e attese che i suoi occhi si abituarono. I tavoli erano puliti e gli strumenti messi al loro posto. Una porta sul retro si apriva su un corridoio illuminato da una lanterna.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Quando entrò nella sala principale capì che aveva sottovalutato l'età e la grandezza di questo posto. Pensava che la biblioteca della sue vecchia gilda dei maghi fosse ampia, ma non aveva mai visto cosi tanti libri. La sala era piena di scaffali con libri in pelle di ogni colore, tutti rivolti verso l'esterno. Numerosi corridoi scendevano nelle catacombe, tutti pieni di libri. Anton si disperò quando pensò a come avrebbe fatto a trovare un singolo libro tra tutti questi, ma poi vide gli anni iscritti sugli archi dei corridoi.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Entrò nel corridoio più recente, iniziato ad usare solo negli ultimi cinque anni. Camminando direttamente verso la fine della fila. C'era una piccola iscrizione sotto l'ultimo libro. Qualche nome Malakim; comunque il libro era troppo scuro e aveva il tatuaggio di un leone sulla copertina. Il penultimo era di color marrone chiaro, come un prato secco. L'incisione sottostante recitava "sconosciuto" insieme all'anno della morte. Il libro prima era grigio verde con un singolo corno che fuoriusciva dal dorso. Prese quello color marrone chiaro. Era alto circa due mani e largo poco di meno. La copertina era leggera, era cuoio dopo tutto. Il dorso era rigido. Osso? Immaginò fosse lo sterno di lei, e penso ai suoi seni, uno senza pelle, l'altro semplicemente morto. Aprì la copertina e fece scorrere il dito lungo il dorso. Le pagine erano state cucite alla copertina usando corde fatte di capelli castani. C'erano delle scritte sulla prima pagina, in un inchiostro che era ancora rossastro e non era ancora diventato marrone. Diceva: Mio caro Ain, Non leggerai mai questo, ma spero tu sappia che ti amerò per sempre. Un brivido lo scosse. Mise il libro di Sebill nella sacca e tornò alla sala principale.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Guardò alle date sopra gli archi, ed entrò nel corridoio successivo. Entrambi i lati del corridoio erano pieni di libri che si fronteggiavano. Un miscuglio di nomi si formo nella sua testa mentre leggeva le iscrizioni.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Stai cercando qualcosa, Anton?" Si girò per vedere Odea al centro del corridoio. Sembrava rilassata; fece del suo meglio per apparire altrettanto rilassato. Il suo grembiule era sparito ed era vestita in maniera confortevole, stupendo Anton in quanto piuttosto carina.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Um... si. Un libro. Un libro di... mio nonno."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Qualcos'altro?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"...No."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Qual'è il suo nome?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton guardò verso la sala principale per vedere se Odea era da sola. "Gerard Cormand."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Lo conosco! Abbastanza rivoluzionario per i suoi tempi. Lo conoscevi?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No. Mio padre si opponeva alle sue politiche e lasciò la città, portandosi dietro la famiglia. Io sono nato in una fattoria."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Tuo nonno fu ucciso prima che la rivoluzione finisse, non è vero?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Si. Devo sapere che non è stato... mio padre."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Tuo nonno è li," indicando più in la nel corridoio. Anton seguì la sua guida cautamente. "I nostri divinatori ebbero un successo limitato come strumenti di scrittura dei morti, permettendogli di fare un ultima dichiarazione."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I morti scrivono?" chiese Anton.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Gli chiediamo se c'è qualcosa che vorrebbero dire. Di solito stanno riflettendo su cosa avrebbero fatto diversamente nella vita, quindi hanno un sacco di consigli. Potrebbero elogiare se stessi, o raccontare la storia della loro vita, dopo diamo una breve vacanza ai divinatori per recuperare le forze. Queste sono anime buone, chiariamoci; non vogliamo neppure contemplare i pericoli del fare un libro senza scrupoli."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Quella donna," pensò Anton, "cosa deve aver fatto per renderla cosi preziosa per i Calabim?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Le vittime di omicidio di solito hanno qualcosa da dire..." Odea smise di camminare e si diresse verso un libro, più piccolo di quello di Sebill e più chiaro.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton disse, "Avrà detto il nome dell'omicida?" Odea non rispose, e Anton sollevò il libro di suo nonno. Lo aprì e lesse: Mi piacevano i peccati carnali. Voltò le pagine: vuote. Sospirò profondamente, e mise il libro a posto. Odea fece un passo indietro. "Restituirai anche l'altro libro?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton affrontò Odea con una posizione allargata. "No. Mi dispiace, lo sto rubando". Teneva un coltello all'altezza degli occhi di lei e prese a muoversi lentamente verso di lei.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Non posso fermarti," lei disse calma. "Ma questo è un'errore. Questi libri sono estremamente pericolosi nelle mani sbagliate. Non devono mai uscire."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Lo so. I vostri "clienti" non mi hanno lasciato scelta però." Giravano in tondo in una cauta danza. Vedendo la sala principale libera, Anton uscì dalla porta principale.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Fuori dalle mura cittadine, Anton raggiunse il suo cavallo, ci montò sopra, e si diresse verso nord. Non era andato molto lontano quando un'improvviso vento, o quello che a lui sembrava vento, lo fece cadere da cavallo, facendogli cadere la sacca. Vide nel buio la sagoma di un gargoyle, le sue ali che bloccavano la luce della città. Corse, e sarebbe morto sul posto se non fosse stato per la magia Rapidità. Invece, morì al limite della foresta poco più in la, mentre il Libro di Sebill rimase vicino alla strada.
TEXT.Spanish: Sebill arrived at a door marked "Acquisitions." The coachman escorted her to the door and gave it two hard knocks. It opened to reveal a miniscule butcher. The dwarf looked up at the coachman and noted Sebill. "Good! Good!" he said and ushered them into what looked like a carpenter's workshop-only one in which the wood bled when cut. "I commend you on your haste; we here are great appreciators of body magic, you know. You ought to be well paid for your effort. Do you need new horses?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"They are well," answered the coachman, "they're of strong breed and can withstand the spells. With enough food and rest tonight they'll have their stamina back."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"They're fine animals, aren't they?" the dwarf said affably, clearing tools off a table. He was joined by a graying female dwarf wearing an equally dirty apron. "Splendid!" she said. "Let's get started. I'm Odea, he's Hahm, in case he didn't introduce himself."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Anton," said the coachman.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Odea turned to examine Sebill. "Let's get a look at you... Even better than I expected! Let's get you on the table." Anton stepped forward to help lift Sebill, but saw it was unnecessary as Odea, despite her size, moved Sebill to the dwarf-sized table without effort. Odea smiled, "She's empty. No organs. I asked our clients in Nubia to clean her to prevent spoiling. Kept out of the sun the bodies can make the trip in adequate shape." Anton nodded. Odea thought he seemed uneasy. "I'm sorry, did you know her?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No, no... I have no idea who she is, or why she's important to the nobles. She doesn't look like an aristocrat." He paused, then motioned toward the door, "I have the rest of the delivery in my carriage."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Her blood I'm sure. Would you fetch that? Hahm needs to check it and make sure the preservers held up. There are a number of naturally occurring blood thinners in just about every land, but ours are better. I have some theories about speeding the reactions to make the ink less corrosive, but that would require entropy mana which can be hard to come by..."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Outside, Anton gave the blood to Hahm and moved his horses into the shade. This was his first visit to the Luchuirp lands. He admitted to himself that he'd always been a little racist toward dwarves, but couldn't think of any reason why. He looked at and admired the structure of the Catacomb Libralus; from what he'd heard he assumed it was nothing more than a one-trick curiosity shop. It was originally built as a catacomb open to all, until necromancers developed a habit of exploiting it, leading to the pejoration of the name "Free-Use Catacombs." Later it was acquired by a wealthy polymath, who turned it into the institution that is now commonly nicknamed the "Catacomb Librarius." Above ground it was a simple structure with short walls and an entrance adorned with arches and pillars.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton returned to the workshop to see Odea in the process of skinning Sebill. Incisions ran up the middle of her chest, along her collarbone, and above her hips. Odea was paring the fatty membrane holding skin to muscle as she pulled the skin upward. Anton groaned at the sight, which alerted Odea that he'd returned. She explained, her enthusiasm outweighing her sympathy for Anton's uneasiness, "The skin's in good shape. We use it all. Her back-because its smoother and thicker-will be tanned and used to make the cover. The rest we stretch into vellum for the pages." Odea paused, Anton was staring at Sebill's body. "It's not pretty, I know. This is an honorable afterlife though. I used to do golemcraft, but animating a golem is like rolling a stone down a hill-it's predictable, it's all it does. Books are the perfect synthesis of form and function, body and spirit, mythos and logos. They are us in every way." She put down her knife, and Anton sat on short ladder. Odea continued, "We can put any talent to use here. Do you practice magic?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I do some, just tricks to help my deliveries-speed the horses, hide my wares. Just dabblings."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ice! Imagine what you could do with ice mana! We could add people from any corner of Erebus to our collection. You could make your fortune just transporting food to soldiers. Ah, if only we could get some..." Anton laughed. He'd thought of this before. Odea continued, "We use a range of magic here: body helps us transform the person, but that's mostly handiwork; our diviners use spirit magic to contact the dead; and enchanters can infuse the books with special properties. Luckily we're in a land where necromancy is outlawed, or we'd have a lot to worry about. Should I take you to see some of our collection?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Thank you," he replied, "but I have to stable my horses first. I should find an inn."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Fine by me. I need to work and I can't have distractions. Come back later for a tour." Odea smiled, "Now get out of here."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A week had passed since Anton delivered Sebill. He'd gone north to meet a Calabim rendezvous who took the carriage, leaving Anton with a horse. Now returning to the fortified city, he spent the evening at a public house, waiting for nightfall. He made his way back to the Catacomb Libralus and to the door marked "Acquisitions." He knocked. If Odea answered he'd have an excuse for being there. If she didn't, then things would be according to plan. He picked the lock and slipped inside. There was barely any light and he waited for his eyes to adjust. The tables were clean and the tools put away. A door in back opened to a lantern-lit corridor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When he entered the main hall he realized he'd underestimated the age and grandeur of this place. He thought the library at his former mages' guild was large, but he'd never seen this many books. The hall was lined with shelves of books in every skin color, all facing out. Numerous corridors descended into the catacombs, all filled with books. Anton despaired when he wondered how he would find a single book in all this, until he saw the years inscribed above the corridors' arches.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He entered the most recent corridor, which had just started to be used in the last five years. He walked straight to the end of the row. A small engraving was underneath the last book. Some Malakim name; the book was too dark anyway and had a tattoo of a lion on the cover. The second-to-last book was a pale tan, like a dry meadow. The engraving underneath read "unknown" and named the year of death. The book before that was grayish green and had a single horn jutting out from the spine. He picked up the tan one. It was about two hands tall and a little less wide. The cover was soft-it was leather after all. The spine was sturdy. Bone? He imagined it was her sternum, and thought of her breasts, one skinless, the other just dead. He opened the cover and ran his finger along the inside spine. The pages were sewn to the cover using string made of brown hair. There was writing on the first page, in ink that was still reddish and had not faded into brown. It said: My dear Ain-You'll never read this, but please know that I love you eternally. A chill shook him. He tucked Sebill's book into his pack and returned to the main hall.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He looked at the dates above the arches, and walked down the next corridor. Both sides of the corridor were lined with books facing each other. A jumble of names grew in his head as he scanned the engravings.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Are you looking for something, Anton?" He spun to see Odea in the middle of the corridor. She looked relaxed; he tried his best to appear the same. Her apron was gone and she was dressed comfortably, striking Anton as quite pretty.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Um... yes. A book. A book of... my grandfather."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Anything else?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"...No."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"What was his name?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton glanced toward the main hall to see if Odea was alone. "Gerard Cormand."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I know of him! Quite the revolutionary in his day. Did you know him?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I didn't. My father opposed his politics and left the city, taking his family along. I was born on a farm."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Your grandfather was murdered before the revolution ended, wasn't he?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes. I have to know that it wasn't... my father."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Your grandfather is here," she pointed farther down the corridor. Anton cautiously followed her lead. "Our diviners enjoy limited success as a writing tool for the dead, allowing them to make a final statement."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"The dead write?" probed Anton.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We ask them if there's anything they'd like to say. They're usually thinking about what they would have done differently in life, so they're full of advice. They might eulogize themselves, or tell their entire life's story-we give the diviners a short vacation to recover after those. These are good souls, mind you; we don't even want to know the dangers of making an unscrupulous book."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"That woman," thought Anton, "what had she done to make her so valuable to the Calabim?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Victims of murder usually have something to say..." Odea stopped walking and motioned toward a book, smaller than Sebill's and paler.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton said, "Would he have named his killer?" Odea didn't answer, and Anton lifted his grandfather's book. He opened it and read: I liked the fleshy sins best. He turned the pages: blank. He sighed deeply, and put the book down. Odea took a step back. "Are you going to return the other book too?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Anton faced Odea with a widened stance. "No. I'm sorry, but I'm stealing it." He held a knife at her eye level and took a slow step toward her.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I can't stop you," she said calmly. "This is a mistake though. These books are extremely dangerous in the wrong hands. They must never leave."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I know. Your clients' haven't given me any choice though." They circled each other in a cautious dance. Seeing the main hall clear, Anton left through the front door.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Outside the city walls, Anton snuck to his horse, mounted her, and pointed her back north. He hadn't ridden far when a sudden strong wind, or that's what it felt like, threw him off his horse, spilling his pack. He saw in the dark the looming shape of a gargoyle, its wings blocking the light from the city. He ran, and would have died on the spot if it weren't for his haste spell. Instead, he died at the forest's edge a short length away, while the Book of Sebill remained beside the road.

TEXT.English: The library's majesty would be a thing of legend. Sebill's view from the fifth floor spanned from the northern slums out to Nubia's western wall and beyond that to where the countryside was trampled underfoot by mountains. Moving a crate of books, new acquisitions from the latest campaigns, she broke her gaze from the window. She was at odds with herself; technically, she'd achieved her goal and become a chief librarian at the world's greatest library. It was what she had promised her childhood friends she'd do, then they in turn would dream up something they thought was even more fantastic. Yet here she was. Slaving. Forced into her wishes' fulfillment by ravenous men under a new moon.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Her town was alight with burning houses as she woke to the screams. She shook her husband awake, scrambled for her weapon, and used it on the first blood-drenched man who burst into the bedroom. His comrades behind him overpowered her. All she could remember feeling at that moment was insult at the fact that they showed no desire to kill her. Instead, one man constrained her on the bed while they dragged her husband outside. She shrieked and swung her fists, until an attacker brought a torch into the room. In the light the men saw the bedroom and its bookshelf-lined walls. Their faces flushed with joy and they shouted congratulations to each other. That was when they knocked her unconscious.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]...there's no noise what's going on? I'm deaf no I'm dead oh good there's noise the chains oh damn me the chains. How dare they keep me down here what did they do to her the next time one of them comes down here I'll wrap these chains around him... Where is everybody I'm alone I'm alone they'll never come for me I'll die here what have they done with her I'll starve here if my heart doesn't explode first I just want to tear them to pieces! Can't stop shaking the walls are too noisy I can't hear myself how can I... Huh? They're coming those are footsteps I'll kill them and I'll get out and find her oh I'll never see her again... One footsteps two feet could it be her they don't sound hard... oh my angel what if it's her she's come to kill me oh my angel it is her![\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sebill hadn't seen her husband since. And now there she was, the woman she'd always wanted to be. Only the library wasn't what she'd hoped for. It was supposed to be a paragon of learning, open to all, with a collection spanning history and all of Erebus. This was a perversion, a library of spoils, built on the sudden whim of that monstrous queen Alexis to actually know something about the people she and her brother were slaughtering. And she'd let Flauros build it! It was a wonder he had any slaves left over to clean up the blood of those who built it. Sebill was horrified to hear that Alexis had been the one to finally build Erebus's greatest library, now known as the Library of Alexis. Sebill never wanted anything to do with it, but now she was its chief archivist. It was more of a wound than a title. Still, she had books. She passed the time by imagining that the library had been built by someone else: perhaps in the Kuriotate lands it would be a bridge across race and politics; in Amurite lands its knowledge would be treated with proper respect.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Books, protected by sturdy leather covers, were durable and could last ages if properly cared for. But books in Erebus were only as permanent as societies allowed. Warring nations expunged conquered peoples' libraries with the rest of their culture. The Age of Ice preserved the previous ages' treasures well, as long as firewood was more plentiful than books. The real damage came with the destruction of literate societies who knew the value of old histories and treatises. Still, Sebill thought, maybe Alexis's collection will serve some good in the long run. Perhaps Sebill's dreams were not totally lost. Spending her days cataloging family histories, journals, folktales, scientific works, philosophies, and everything else brought in from homes and palace libraries gave her faith that one day this could be shared with the world.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She unloaded the books onto the table-They were her books. She stared at them, telling herself that this was inevitable, and yet she was holding the books that belonged to her and her former neighbors. She tried to detach herself, but opening the covers felt like tearing new flesh off wounds. "Is this the last I'll ever see of my life?" she despaired. One book confirmed that it would be: a ledger, a report of the raid on her town.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]it's her it's her she came for me she sees me she'll kill me I have to kill her I'm scared I hate her I hate those men that's a sharp knife I'm going to die I should die I'm worthless I'm afraid hate hate them her skin cuts so fine[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Come on you. Drink up."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]blood! she's bleeding I can taste it already these chains hurt I want her to notice me let me go I must taste her fingers the cut is so sharp I can feel the cut on my tongue I'm okay I'll be okay she loves me I'm home I'm hers her hand is so soft it could tear me to pieces I want her to she can have me all in little bits she'll protect me my angel my angel I'll climb under her shadow her dress I'll be engulfed in her darkness her peaceful darkness she'll hold me and I'll be okay I'll be hers I'll be nothing in her abyss she loves me she will always protect me...[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sneaking out was unnecessary. Sebill doubted it was because they trusted her; perhaps they were certain they could find her if she ran off. The masters ignored other slaves, but had to address her because of the role they gave her. Eye contact was rare, but they had an odd way of acknowledging her presence by letting her know they were smelling her. Tonight she was betting they wouldn't find her quickly enough.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The ledger had listed the spoils, the "acquisitions." House #6 Contents. Books: 156. Woman: Educated: For especial use, she read. Man: Drunk, superior physical condition: For conscription in Red Barracks. Weapons only other items of value. She knew of the so-called "Red Barracks." Other librarians spoke fearfully, sorrowfully, of their loved ones sent there.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She agonized during the following nights. After her life had been destroyed her only possible comfort was having all the world's books and time enough at last to read. Now that had become her hell. The only truth she wanted was outside the library. She had to find the Red Barracks.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]And she did. She was ushered right in through the front doors the moment she was spotted sneaking underneath a window. She protested, feigned ignorance, fought, but was pulled before a woman wrapping her hand in a bandage. Sebill froze; her. Alexis looked at Sebill with a sneer.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Mistress, we found her snooping. She looks like-"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I don't care what she is. Come. Bring her." She turned and walked with her saturating, scarlet-bandaged hand at her side.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Bring her in here."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sebill was thrown to the floor in a small, windowless room. The light from the room outside shone past her, and onto a man chained to the wall. Sebill bounced to her feet, but was stunned when she saw him.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ain! Oh!" she shouted and ran to him. He stared at her without recognition and his lips trembled with senseless mutterings. Alexis entered the room and watched with contempt as Sebill tried to get Ain to look at her. Ain was transfixed by Alexis. Suddenly a look of eagerness showed on his face and he noticed Sebill for the first time.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ain! It's me, dear!" She shook Ain and rubbed his cheeks in growing hysteria. Her eyes widened in both fear and hope when Ain looked at her. In him she saw savagery mixed with his eagerness to please. Four eyes with four different emotions looked at each other across the chasm of their broken lives. Ain then looked to Alexis, who remained still and observant in the doorway. She was glad-tonight she had something interesting to give the new recruit. She was losing interest in tossing unsatisfactory guards to these things.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sebill, nearly sobbing, tried futilely to find her husband in this man. Ain, however, flourished in the queen's attention. Sebill was too confused to react when Ain grabbed her throat and throttled her. He found little resistance from her body as Alexis's blood burned inside him. His wife's essence slipped away and Ain looked to his queen for affirmation.

Sebill's view from the fifth floor spanned from the northern slums out to Nubia's western wall and beyond that to where the countryside was trampled underfoot by mountains. Moving a crate of books, new acquisitions from the latest campaigns, she broke her gaze from the window. She was at odds with herself; technically, she'd achieved her goal and become a chief librarian at the world's greatest library. It was what she had promised her childhood friends she'd do, then they in turn would dream up something they thought was even more fantastic. Yet here she was. Slaving. Forced into her wishes' fulfillment by ravenous men under a new moon.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Her town was alight with burning houses as she woke to the screams. She shook her husband awake, scrambled for her weapon, and used it on the first blood-drenched man who burst into the bedroom. His comrades behind him overpowered her. All she could remember feeling at that moment was insult at the fact that they showed no desire to kill her. Instead, one man constrained her on the bed while they dragged her husband outside. She shrieked and swung her fists, until an attacker brought a torch into the room. In the light the men saw the bedroom and its bookshelf-lined walls. Their faces flushed with joy and they shouted congratulations to each other. That was when they knocked her unconscious.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]...there's no noise what's going on? I'm deaf no I'm dead oh good there's noise the chains oh damn me the chains. How dare they keep me down here what did they do to her the next time one of them comes down here I'll wrap these chains around him... Where is everybody I'm alone I'm alone they'll never come for me I'll die here what have they done with her I'll starve here if my heart doesn't explode first I just want to tear them to pieces! Can't stop shaking the walls are too noisy I can't hear myself how can I... Huh? They're coming those are footsteps I'll kill them and I'll get out and find her oh I'll never see her again... One footsteps two feet could it be her they don't sound hard... oh my angel what if it's her she's come to kill me oh my angel it is her![\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sebill hadn't seen her husband since. And now there she was, the woman she'd always wanted to be. Only the library wasn't what she'd hoped for. It was supposed to be a paragon of learning, open to all, with a collection spanning history and all of Erebus. This was a perversion, a library of spoils, built on the sudden whim of that monstrous queen Alexis to actually know something about the people she and her brother were slaughtering. And she'd let Flauros build it! It was a wonder he had any slaves left over to clean up the blood of those who built it. Sebill was horrified to hear that Alexis had been the one to finally build Erebus's greatest library, now known as the Library of Alexis. Sebill never wanted anything to do with it, but now she was its chief archivist. It was more of a wound than a title. Still, she had books. She passed the time by imagining that the library had been built by someone else: perhaps in the Kuriotate lands it would be a bridge across race and politics; in Amurite lands its knowledge would be treated with proper respect.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Books, protected by sturdy leather covers, were durable and could last ages if properly cared for. But books in Erebus were only as permanent as societies allowed. Warring nations expunged conquered peoples' libraries with the rest of their culture. The Age of Ice preserved the previous ages' treasures well, as long as firewood was more plentiful than books. The real damage came with the destruction of literate societies who knew the value of old histories and treatises. Still, Sebill thought, maybe Alexis's collection will serve some good in the long run. Perhaps Sebill's dreams were not totally lost. Spending her days cataloging family histories, journals, folktales, scientific works, philosophies, and everything else brought in from homes and palace libraries gave her faith that one day this could be shared with the world.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She unloaded the books onto the table-They were her books. She stared at them, telling herself that this was inevitable, and yet she was holding the books that belonged to her and her former neighbors. She tried to detach herself, but opening the covers felt like tearing new flesh off wounds. "Is this the last I'll ever see of my life?" she despaired. One book confirmed that it would be: a ledger, a report of the raid on her town.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]it's her it's her she came for me she sees me she'll kill me I have to kill her I'm scared I hate her I hate those men that's a sharp knife I'm going to die I should die I'm worthless I'm afraid hate hate them her skin cuts so fine[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Come on you. Drink up."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]blood! she's bleeding I can taste it already these chains hurt I want her to notice me let me go I must taste her fingers the cut is so sharp I can feel the cut on my tongue I'm okay I'll be okay she loves me I'm home I'm hers her hand is so soft it could tear me to pieces I want her to she can have me all in little bits she'll protect me my angel my angel I'll climb under her shadow her dress I'll be engulfed in her darkness her peaceful darkness she'll hold me and I'll be okay I'll be hers I'll be nothing in her abyss she loves me she will always protect me...[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sneaking out was unnecessary. Sebill doubted it was because they trusted her; perhaps they were certain they could find her if she ran off. The masters ignored other slaves, but had to address her because of the role they gave her. Eye contact was rare, but they had an odd way of acknowledging her presence by letting her know they were smelling her. Tonight she was betting they wouldn't find her quickly enough.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The ledger had listed the spoils, the "acquisitions." House #6 Contents. Books: 156. Woman: Educated: For especial use, she read. Man: Drunk, superior physical condition: For conscription in Red Barracks. Weapons only other items of value. She knew of the so-called "Red Barracks." Other librarians spoke fearfully, sorrowfully, of their loved ones sent there.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She agonized during the following nights. After her life had been destroyed her only possible comfort was having all the world's books and time enough at last to read. Now that had become her hell. The only truth she wanted was outside the library. She had to find the Red Barracks.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]And she did. She was ushered right in through the front doors the moment she was spotted sneaking underneath a window. She protested, feigned ignorance, fought, but was pulled before a woman wrapping her hand in a bandage. Sebill froze; her. Alexis looked at Sebill with a sneer.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Mistress, we found her snooping. She looks like-"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I don't care what she is. Come. Bring her." She turned and walked with her saturating, scarlet-bandaged hand at her side.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Bring her in here."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sebill was thrown to the floor in a small, windowless room. The light from the room outside shone past her, and onto a man chained to the wall. Sebill bounced to her feet, but was stunned when she saw him.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ain! Oh!" she shouted and ran to him. He stared at her without recognition and his lips trembled with senseless mutterings. Alexis entered the room and watched with contempt as Sebill tried to get Ain to look at her. Ain was transfixed by Alexis. Suddenly a look of eagerness showed on his face and he noticed Sebill for the first time.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ain! It's me, dear!" She shook Ain and rubbed his cheeks in growing hysteria. Her eyes widened in both fear and hope when Ain looked at her. In him she saw savagery mixed with his eagerness to please. Four eyes with four different emotions looked at each other across the chasm of their broken lives. Ain then looked to Alexis, who remained still and observant in the doorway. She was glad-tonight she had something interesting to give the new recruit. She was losing interest in tossing unsatisfactory guards to these things.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sebill, nearly sobbing, tried futilely to find her husband in this man. Ain, however, flourished in the queen's attention. Sebill was too confused to react when Ain grabbed her throat and throttled her. He found little resistance from her body as Alexis's blood burned inside him. His wife's essence slipped away and Ain looked to his queen for affirmation.
